comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Typo in caption. Should be "off" Ostend. Another LoC view of the same location. Notice the towers/spires.

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: The original image appears highly edited. The troops in the foreground are from a different source photo than cannons, which are again a different source photo from the background itself.

comment.author: 90391304@N00
comment._content: I agree with bior. Not to mention the flags.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: The First Ostend Raid (part of Operation ZO) was the first of two attacks by the Royal Navy on the German-held port of Ostend during the late spring of 1918 during the First World War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Ostend_Raid

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The airship looks like it's pasted in, too.  Since this is earlier than 1918 in the general Bain picture flow, this might be an illustration from closer to the time the Germans took Ostend in mid-October, 1914.  Are those German flags flying and German soldiers on the embankment?

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: At bottom left is the logo of Neue Photographische Gesellschaft m.b.H. (NPG) de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neue_Photographische_Gesellschaft a Berlin company. Hence this is probably a German photograph.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: I wondered about the date too..  I didn't see an earlier raid so that makes the most sense.  It must have been an active place during the war!

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: good catch, swanq.. The subject matter is pretty pro-German as well.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: From what I can see, although I haven't found a good timeline, the Belgians had abandoned Antwerp in October 10, 1914, and of the British who had been coming to their aid in Ostend, some were taken off by sea and others retreated on land. A week later there are reports of the British navy attacking Ostend and the Germans bringing in new guns. One illustration of what was going on at this time is at www.historyofwar.org/articles/weapons_HMS_Humber.html The British expected to reoccupy Ostend soon, but that did not happen.

comment.author: 34911459@N08
comment._content: swang: thanks for catching the typo.  We will update the record.  And thanks for the background information on the war and about the photograph.
